__data__.text: Central southern Turkey and northwestern Syria are located in a tectonically active region, resulting from the interaction of three plates: the African, Arabian, and Anatolian Plates. The boundary between the African and Arabian Plates is defined by the Dead Sea Transform (DST), a significant left-lateral strike-slip fault accommodating the northward movement of the Arabian Plate in relation to Africa.

In the tectonically active region of central southern Turkey and northwestern Syria, the northern end of the Dead Sea Transform fault, which marks the boundary between the African and Arabian Plates and moves northward, intersects with the westward-moving East Anatolian Fault, which accommodates the extrusion of the Anatolian Plate caused by the Arabian Plate's northward movement. This intersection occurs at the Marash Triple Junction.

The Dead Sea Transform (DST) and the East Anatolian Fault (EAF) intersect at the Marash Triple Junction, with the EAF extending westward and merging into the Cyprus arc via the Latakia Ridge. The EAF is a 700 km-long fault, split into seven segments, stretching from the northeast: Karlıova, Ilıca, Palu, Pütürge, Erkenek, Pazarcık, and Amanos.

The Amanos segment of the East Anatolian Fault (EAF) is linked to the Dead Sea Transform (DST) and viewed as a transitional structure or part of the DST by certain geologists. Additionally, a northern branch of the EAF has been identified, which consists of several segments extending from Sürgü to Düziçi–İskenderun.

The slip rate along the main part of the East Anatolian Fault (EAF) system reduces progressively in a southwest direction, from 10 mm/year on the Karlıova segment to 2.9 mm/year on the Amanos segment. A slip rate of 2.5 mm/year has been determined for the Çardak segment, which is part of the northern EAF branch that spans from Sürgü to Düziçi–İskenderun. The Sürgü-Çardak Fault is a 160 km-long, east-west striking fault situated north of the EAF.

The Sürgü Fault, part of the northern EAF branch, stretches for 70 km from Çelikhan to Nurhak, and the Çardak Fault runs for 90 km from Nurhak to Göksun. Seismic activity on these faults is limited, with only one recorded M 6.8 earthquake in 1544. The northern part of the DST is divided into multiple segments, but there is some debate among scientists about which faults belong to the DST or the EAF at the structure's northernmost end. The slip rate along the EAF system decreases progressively in a southwest direction, from 10 mm/year on the Karlıova segment to 2.9 mm/year on the Amanos segment, with a slip rate of 2.5 mm/year determined for the Çardak segment.
